properties.name: ARMENIANS, 1915, Armenian Genocide
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderturkeyper http://www.armenian-genocide.org/ "The main thrust of the Armenian Genocide, however, was implemented within the first year of the war, years ahead of any imminent collapse. While the mass deportations of the civilian Armenian population was carried out in the spring and summer of 1915 and were completed by the fall, the systematic slaughter of the Armenians had started earlier with the murder of the able-bodied males already drafted into the Ottoman armed forces. By expropriating the movable and immovable wealth of the Armenians, the CUP also looked upon its policy of genocide as a means for enriching its coffers and rewarding its cohorts. The elimination of a commercially viable minority fulfilled part of the nationalist program to concentrate financial power in the hands of the state and promote greater Turkish control over the domestic economy."

properties.name: Aldies Grocery Store
properties.description: Posted by Oleander4000 market st phildelphia pa 19143An excellent place to stock up on necessary supplies when preparing to dig into the bomb shelter built into the basement. Also a good place to meet up with people as the EL stops right there. Of course, depending on who you are and who you know, you may not recieve a friendly welcome and people may or may not admit to having seen you.

properties.name: Anchor Town - The Iceberg
properties.description: Posted by PlacekraftAnchorage, AK

properties.name: April 15, 2006 Curtis Jackson, 32, of Mount Laurel,NJ
properties.description: Posted by OleanderFerry Avenue Camden NJDarnell M. Cloud, 26, of Camden and several other men had been fighting at the Cafe II nightclub before security broke them up. In parking lot a short time later, Cloud pulled out a handgun, shot one of the bouncers, and then got into a car and sped away - he remains at large. Curtis Jackson, 32, of Mount Laurel, died of a gunshot to the head.

properties.name: April 19, 2006, Unnamed Newborn, less than an hour old
properties.description: Posted by OleanderLudlow Street philadelphia paPer Philly.com: "Tanjia Fredericks made sure to disconnect herself from the dying infant and cut off the baby\'s umbilical cord, cops said, before ignoring her son\'s first and last moments of life. "Police said the companion did not know that Fredericks had just given birth. Rather, Fredericks told him she was having a miscarriage. The companion has not been charged in the case. Medics rushed to the companion\'s home about 2:30 a.m. the next day - three hours after the infant was born, police said. They found the limp newborn with his head still under water. He was pronounced dead 20 minutes later. The coroner ruled asphyxiation as the cause of death. Police charged Fredericks with murder, involuntary manslaughter and child endangerment. She was arrested while getting treated at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania."

properties.name: April 20, 2006 Yagouba Bah, 17
properties.description: Posted by Oleander6000 North A Street philadelphia paPer Philly.com: "Yagouba Bah, 17, of the 100 block of West Champlost Street, was shot twice and stabbed so brutally Thursday night that one police official said the wound looked as though the victim had been eviscerated on the playground. And, police said, it all happened in front of the teen\'s brother. Maurice Harmon, 17, of the 5800 block of Howard Street, was shot in the thigh accidentally by a friend during the slaying of Bah, police said. Harmon was treated for injuries - and charged yesterday with murder. He is a junior at a school run by Community Education Partners at 12th Street and Allegheny Avenue. Police said the teens had a running argument earlier in the evening. Witnesses told police the fights flared and calmed, and then, before one teen starting swinging a stick, another pulled a knife and two pulled guns. Capt. Benjamin Naish, a police spokesman, said Bah had been getting the better of the other teens before it escalated with weapons. Police said Bah had not been armed. Police said the nature of the argument was unclear. They also had not determined who took Harmon to the hospital for his leg injury.

properties.name: At work
properties.description: Posted by Oleandercolumbia MOI was working with a group of computer geeks who were in the habit of creating bogus websites and trying to pass them off as real events to coworkers. Therefore, it was lunchtime (when I walked in to see CNN broadcasts on the lunchroom television) before I realized this thing was real.

properties.name: BOSNIAK, July 1995, Srebrenica massacre
properties.description: Posted by OleanderSrebrenica Per Wikipedia: "The Srebrenica massacre was the July 1995 killing of an estimated 8,102 Bosniak males, ranging in age from teenagers to the elderly, in the region of Srebrenica in Bosnia and Herzegovina by a Serb Army of Republika Srpska under general Ratko Mladić including Serbian state special forces "Scorpions"."

properties.name: Beluga Whale
properties.description: Posted by Oleander4311 Main Street manayunk PAA Beluga Whale appeared in the Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers in April 2005. There was such an uproar that there was a local bakery that saw an increase in income due to their Beluga Whale cookies. The riverways are clean enough to attract a whale. Weeeee! I suppose there\'s always reason to celebrate when the waters aren\'t so toxic that they kill all living creatures within them...well, toxic anymore.

properties.name: Boston MA - Father's side
properties.description: Posted by Oleandernewbury st, boston, maMy father and his parents lived here (I think he was born and raised here, but I\'m not sure)

properties.name: Boundary Waters
properties.description: Posted by Oleander Boundary Waters of MinnesotaMany years (decades now) I spent the better part of a summer here. I was working with a group of volunteers building trails and bridges and the like. We lived on an island and traveled by canoe. Our only contact with the outside world was a walkie talkie and our only way off the island was a park service boat. There were rough spots, granted, but I will never get over living in a tent surrounded by bear, moose, eagles, and gods only know what else. The distance of time have turned the place into a land of mysticsm. I honestly wish I could do that kind of camping again.

properties.name: Brazil
properties.description: Posted by OleanderbrazilI\'ve never been to Brazil and I\'m not real sure which area, specifically, I would like to go - I just know that I\'d like to travel there. I\'ve heard they have an entirely sustainable eco-friendly community developed there (though I don\'t know where) and there was an open-source conference/festival (read: geeks with lots of equipment, open source software, and demonstrations of what they\'ve done with it...followed by discourse on the politcs of open source). From what little I know, I am impressed by both the envrinmental attitude and the technological libralism. Of course, there\'s also the natural landscape. frankly, outside of the two things listed already, I know practically nothing about this country - to my mind it\'s a lush green forest with lots of rain and giant flat leaves with water dropping off of them and into lakes or hollowed out trees. But, that\'s one of the reasons why I love to travel - to find out the reality of the world and replace my fragmented assumptions with lived experience.

properties.name: CHEROKEE, 1838, Trail of Tears
properties.description: Posted by OleanderTahlequah OklahomaPer Cherokee.org: "Under orders from President Jackson and in defiance of the U.S. Supreme Court, the U.S. Army began enforcement of the Removal Act. More than 3,000 Cherokees were rounded up in the summer of 1838 and loaded onto boats that traveled the Tennessee, Ohio, Mississippi and Arkansas Rivers into Indian Territory. Many were held in prison camps awaiting their fate. An estimated 4,000 died from hunger, exposure and disease. The journey became an eternal memory as the "trail where they cried" for the Cherokees and other removed tribes. Today, it is remembered as the "Trail of Tears." The Oklahoma Chapter of the Trail of Tears Association has begun the task of marking the graves of Trail survivors with bronze memorials."

properties.name: Chequamegon National Forest
properties.description: Posted by Oleander Medford WISomewhere in this forest (located near the town of Medford) is a little campground with a lake and a full moon that the wolves howl to at night. The campground consists of dirt spots for tents and parking spaces for those who drive instead of hike and fire rings. Not much else - and you drop payment into a bax. Someday I\'ll go back.

properties.name: Deer
properties.description: Posted by Oleander city line ave Bala cynwyd paA deer (no antlers - I think it was Doe, but it was pretty far away). It had a pretty red tinge to it\'s hide but it was also sunrise so it may have been the sun.

properties.name: Devil's Tower National Monument
properties.description: Posted by OleanderDevils Tower, WY 82714There is something about this place that keeps drawing me to it every time I travel through the region. It\'s pretty touristy and more crowded than I would prefer but hiking the trail around the perimeter, carefully navigating from one enormous rock to another until I can practically touch the base of the tower, and feeling the sun (or the rain) set in brilliant reds (that I swear are specific to this one spot in the entire world) is all that I can think about when i find myself within driving distance.

properties.name: Dickeyville Grotto
properties.description: Posted by OleanderWest Main Street Dickeyville, WIMassive quantities of cement with everything imaginable pushed into it. Marbles, spoons,china,various colors of rock, and heaven only knows what else. It\'s supposed to be a holy place for persons interesting in the stations of the cross, attending mass, and buying a rosary (my ex bought his neice her first rosary here), but the STUFF is just...fascinating.

properties.name: Exploits Bay
properties.description: Posted by GabarusNorthern Newfoundland. The land of the Beothuks... or it was once. My wife and I head there in June, to paddle these islands and beyond to see icebergs and whales and to paddle the waterways they once did in birchbark canoes. We will also visit the former Viking settlement of L\'Anse aux Meadows (Meadows Cove) and the Basque whaling station at Red Bay, Labrador. Add over 20 hours on ferries, and it should be a fun trip.

properties.name: Finch
properties.description: Posted by Oleander 9th street and market street philadelphia paIt was a tiny injured bird constantly in danger of being stepped on. People kept looking at it and stepping around it at the last minute. Several couples stopped and stared as if it were a strange freak of nature and they could hardly comprehend it\'s existance. I realized I could not leave it where I found it, so I took my newly purchased jeans out of a plastic bag, caught the bird, smuggled it into a local department store, bought a few items so that I could carry it home, and it \'flew\' away as I was trying to put it into the box. It was more like a desperate flutter/glide/fall over the side of a railing, but it was gone and i could not help it.

properties.name: GUANCHES, 1402-1492, Spanish Invasion
properties.description: Posted by OleanderLas Palmas de Gran CanariaPer Wikipedia "Many of the Guanches fell in resisting the Spaniards, many were sold as slaves, and many conformed to the Roman Catholic faith and married Spaniards." "In 1402, the conquest of the islands began, with the expedition of Juan de Bethencourt and Gadifer de la Salle to the island of Lanzarote. Gadifer would conquer Lanzarote and Fuerteventura with ease since many of the aborigenes, faced with issues of starvation and poor agriculture, would surrender to Spanish Reign." The islands today: http://www.grancanaria.com/

properties.name: Germany - Father's Side
properties.description: Posted by OleanderGermanyMy grandfather denied it but I did a little haphazaard geneological research many years ago and found links to Germany - although I\'m no expert at these things so i have no absolute proof of this. I guess this one falls into a \'maybe\' category

properties.name: Gotham City - The real thing
properties.description: Posted by OleanderGotham WiWhile the comic books are based on New York City, Gotham is actually located in Wisconsin. It\'s a small town, but it\'s a tough town. The gas station sells gas, food, and rifles (which are located in a gun rack right inside the front door).

properties.name: Hawk Mountain
properties.description: Posted by Oleander Hawk MountainThe oldest sanctuary and rehabilitation center for birds of prey in the USA. There\'s a long list of birds that come through hawk Mountain each year as they migrate from one place to another and I like birds - who doesn\'t? This is also a campground with hiking trails and heaven only knows what else. Camping on the mountain where migratory birds like Hawks and Eagles have a safe wayside along their long annual journey doesn\'t have a mystic appeal, per se...something equally as strong but more earthy. It\'s a place to connect with others traveling along their routes home - wherever home may be during this half of the year. I\'ve been hoping to get there for about 5 years now but it just hasn\'t worked out for one reason or another.

properties.name: High Resolution Mass Spectrometry Group
properties.description: Posted by KkmurrayKraków, PolandThe group unites scientists of the Regional Laboratory and the Faculty of Chemistry, Jagiellonian University.

properties.name: Ireland - Father's Side
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderdublin, irelandMy understanding is that a Great Grandmother on my Father\'s side came from somewhere in Ireland and married a norwegian once she landed here.

properties.name: JEWISH, 1933-1944, Auschwitz-Birkenau (Poland), The Holocaust
properties.description: Posted by Oleander    Complete name: Auschwitz, Konzentrationslager Auschwitz-Birkenau, KL Auschwitz Per Wikipedia: "the largest of the Nazi German extermination camps, along with a number of concentration camps, comprising three main camps and 40-50 sub-camps....Beginning in 1940, Nazi Germany built several concentration camps and an extermination camp in the area, which at the time was under German occupation...at least 1.1–1.7 million people were killed there, of whom over 90% were Jews...at least 1.1 million Jews...were killed [at Auschwitz-Birkenau ]..." This is now the site of a historical center preserving the history of the Holocaust: The fortified walls, barbed wire, platforms, barracks, gallows, gas chambers and cremation ovens show the conditions within which the Nazi genocide took place in the former concentration and extermination camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau, the largest in the Third Reich.

properties.name: March 9, 2006, Catherine Smullen, 82
properties.description: Posted by OleanderNedro Avenue and ogontz philadelphia pa Philadelphia Daily News: "Smullen had been attacked "by a knife-wielding thug who hacked her repeatedly in her chest and throat. "Police suspect she knew her killer and might have invited him inside unwittingly. Despite window bars and an alarm system, there was no sign of forced entry. A video camera mounted at the entrance to an elementary school across the street yielded no clues. "Robbery was the likely motive because, police said, some things were "not in place." Investigators suspect the killer may have picked his victim because of her age and infirmity. Smullen had grown increasingly reclusive in recent years as Parkinson\'s disease symptoms and other age-related ailments took their toll."

properties.name: Newfoundland and Labrador Canada - Mother's Side
properties.description: Posted by Oleandernewfoundland and labradorAbout 200 years ago the people from France met up with the people of the Mi\'kmaq tribe and then my ancestors became both French and Mi\'kmaq.

properties.name: Normandy France - Mother's Side
properties.description: Posted by OleanderSeine-Maritime normandy franceYou have to go back to the 1700\'s, but there is a branch of the family that extends to Normandy France. I *think* it\'s the region close to Switzerland, but don\'t hold me to that.

properties.name: Norway - Father's Side
properties.description: Posted by OleandernorwayThe story I recall being told was that my grandmother\'s mother came from Ireland and her father came from Norway.

properties.name: Olympic National Park
properties.description: Posted by Oleander    Glacier capped mountains, wild Pacific coast and magnificent stands of old-growth forests, including temperate rain forests -- at Olympic National Park, you can find all three. About 95% of the park is designated wilderness, which further protects these diverse and spectacular ecosystems.

properties.name: Parc national de la Gaspésie, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts, Québec, Canada
properties.description: Posted by Oleander    Sainte-Anne-des-Monts, Québec, CanadaI am told that one branch of my family stretches out into Quebec Canada. I\'ve had this little thought, way in the back of my mind, that I might go there someday - just to the see the place. But, I long since decided that I\'d rather see the country than the specific farm distant ancestors lived and worked on. I want to see Quebec in the quiet of it\'s natural places. Hardly anything can be called untouched anymore, but the national parks and nature preserves have more to say about the land named for any country you care to mention than the city streets or the guide books. The cities will pass along the nature of the feet that have passed there, but the dirt and trees will tell you about the land itself. http://www.sentier.ca/index.php?lang=en&section_id=1 http://www.sepaq.com/pq/fr/

properties.name: Park on the Ocean's Edge in Seattle WA
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderseattle waI lived here for a while. Honestly, I think its the most beautiful (USA) city I\'ve ever been to and almost the cleanest (worldwide). Besides, I love the ocean and I did not take advantage of my proximity to it anywhere near enough. I would like to find this park (again), and sit on the oceans edge for a while. Then, perhaps, I could jump on a ferry to visit the islands, a boat to see the whales, and a ship to travel onward to Alaska. Maybe...

properties.name: Petroglyphs
properties.description: Posted by Oleandermoab UtahIn this approximate area I saw a sign for Petroglyphs at the next exit. I pulled off at the first wayside, which had it\'s own pet raven and the last outdoor waterpumps on the road headed west. The Petroglyphs were at the end of a long country road that wound through public land. I camped there alone under a full moon and in between fast and short rainstorms.

properties.name: Possum
properties.description: Posted by Oleander59th and overbrook philadelphia paHiding under the bushes, pressed up against the red brick of a house, and eyeing me warily, I initially mistook it for a giant rat. Like most of the animals I\'ve seen in this city, it was neither as clean nor as healthy as I\'ve seen in the same species outside of the city. It gave me a shock in the last light of day and i suspect it felt the same way about me.

properties.name: Quebec Canada - Mother's Side
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderquebec canadaSomewhere in this province many generations on my mother\'s side have lived and worked as farmers. They also spoke French (if that was not already assumed).

properties.name: ROMANIES, ROMA, SINTI, MANUSH (AKA: Gypsies), 1933-1944, Auschwitz-Birkenau (Poland), The Holocaust
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderauschwitz polandPer Wikipedia: "Proportional to their population, the death toll of Romanies (Roma, Sinti, and Manush) in the Holocaust was the worst of any group of victims... Between a quarter and a half of the Romani population was killed, upwards of 220,000 people.[10] In Eastern Europe, Roma were deported to the Jewish ghettoes, shot by SS Einsatzgruppen in their villages, and deported and gassed in Auschwitz and Treblinka."

properties.name: Raccoon
properties.description: Posted by Oleander 4721 baltimore avenue philadelphia paAn unusually pale Raccoon scurried out of an alley, past the garbage cans in that alley, and across the street. It ducked under a car and disappeared. It was clearly a raccoon, but I have never seen one with fur that grey-white before.

properties.name: River Otter in the Schuylkill River
properties.description: Posted by Oleander17th street and market street philadelphia paBig news in April of 2005 - a River Otter was spotted near a fish ladder in the Schuylkill! Everyone on the news was cheering away because it was possible for wildlife to live in the Philadelphia water! For some reason I couldn\'t quite get over this nasty feeling of unease that this was something people had reason to be REALLY happy about...A river so polluted that it\'s to toxic for a river otter to live (or, at least, find food) is...disturbing.

properties.name: Rock Doves (AKA: Squab or Pigeons)
properties.description: Posted by Oleander 30th street and market street philadelphia paWhile waiting for one of the SEPTA trains you can look up into the roof over the platform and see a large balloon with a target-like image on it\'s side. This is a tool for scaring away birds. It\'s supposed to frighten all non-birds-of-prey. It amuses me to see it up there, spotted with bird poop, obviously not working. The reason it does not work is because it\'s built to imitate the markings of a bird of prey. However, the Squab in the train station have never seen, much less been attacked by, a hawk or an owl. So, the big balloon with the taget on it\'s side is just that - a big balloon with a target on it\'s side. A couple of hunters using trained hawks to reduce the rock dove population would be far more affective.

properties.name: SERBS, 1941-1945, Jasenovac (Croatia), The Holocaust
properties.description: Posted by OleanderJasenovacPer Wikipedia: "Jasenovac was the largest concentration and extermination camp in Croatia during World War II, and the third most "productive" death camp overall, after Auschwitz and Treblinka. It was established by the Ustaša regime of the Independent State of Croatia in August 1941 and headed by Miroslav Majstorović...Due to differing views and lack of documentation, estimates for the number of Serbian victims in Croatia range widely, from 25,000 to more than one million. The estimated number of Serbs killed in Jasenovac ranges from 25,000 to 700,000. The most reliable figures place the number of Serbs killed by the Ustaša between 330,000 and 390,000, with 45,000 to 52,000 Serbs murdered in Jasenovac"

properties.name: Seagulls
properties.description: Posted by Oleander30th street and market st philadelphia paThey will sit on the railing behind the busstop and wait for food to be dropped or tossed. I threw donut peices over the railing and they cuaght them midair. The most interesting thing about them is they way they just sit on the railing, all in a row, and wait. No agressive begging (that I\'ve seen).

properties.name: Soooo cold.....
properties.description: Posted by Epratt76reykjavik icelandCold, windy, snowy, crayons and almost falling off ponies... That\'s what I remember about Iceland as a child.

properties.name: St. Stephen's Cathedral
properties.description: Posted by Oleandervienna, austriaI think this is the right location for the Cathedral, but I\'m not sure because every attempt to enter in the address returned a \'not found\' error. Sometimes it\'s hard to know whether to search in the language of the location or in my own language. Regardless, this is one of those places that I\'ve been to and have rather powerful memories of. All i did ws walk into the Cathedral (2 or 3 times, at the most) and wander around while a man playeed songs I no longer remember on a giant pipe organ. There is something very powerful about the cathedral. It was as though i could sense the presence of every footstep that had passed there. Not in an I-see-ghosts kinda way, but in a this-place-has-the-energy-of-many-worshipers-seeped-into-it\'s-stones manner. The one thing I remember most vividly was a railing on a spiral staircase that was closed to general traffic. The railing consisted of (what felt like) stone that had been carved into a long series of frogs eating one another. The mouth of one was clamped onto the backside of another, and they lay that way from the first step all the way up as far as i could see. The frogs at the very bottom were worn down to the point of almost losing their frog-resemblance. As i touched these fading amphibian railing residents i realized that they had been filed away by the touch of hands that had brushed accross them over centuries of time. While the first step accross the threshold told me this place had a strong power to it, the touch of the frogs was the point where I realized why.

properties.name: Sweden - Mother's Side
properties.description: Posted by OleanderStockholm, swedenMy grandfather\'s parents came to the USA from Sweden

properties.name: TAMIL, July and August 1983, Genocide'83
properties.description: Posted by OleanderSri LankaPer Tamilnation.org: Paul Sieghart in his Report of a Mission to Sri Lanka on behalf of the International Commission of Jurists and its British Section, Justice, March1984, concluded: "Clearly this was not a spontaneous upsurge of communal hatred among the Sinhala people.. It was a series of deliberate acts, executed in accordance with a concerted plan, conceived and organised well in advance. But who were the planners?... Communal riots in which Tamils are killed, maimed, robbed and rendered homeless are no longer isolated episodes; they are beginning to become a pernicious habit." [see 1958, 1961, 1974 and 1977]

properties.name: TUTSI, April 1994 - July 1994, Rwandan Genocide
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderkigali rwandaPer Wikipedia: "Rwandan Genocide was the slaughter of an estimated 800,000 [1] Tutsis and moderate Hutus, mostly carried out by two extremist Hutu militia groups, the Interahamwe and the Impuzamugambi, during a period of 100 days from April 6th through mid-July 1994."

properties.name: The Corn Palace
properties.description: Posted by Oleander601 N. Main St., Mitchell, SDThe corn palace is created and destroyed every year. It\'s a building decorated with corn. It\'s fascinating to see, never mind the tourist-trap keychain and cedar box \'gift\' shops that seem to go with every tourist attraction in the country. The amazin part is on the outside, the run-the-people-through-like-sheep run of the mill story-of-the-palace tour is on the inside. The outside is worth the trip, the inside is...well...eh.

properties.name: The Elvis Still Lives Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Oleander A building with 2 large ars outfront that were once owned by Elvis. Inside this (small) structure, half of the place is dedicated to authentic items owned by Elvis (read: a baby carriage his mother used to put him into), a recreation of Elvis\'s grave, a HUGE document proving that Elvis was employed by the CIA, and similar things. Crammed into the spaces where museuam-like items are not displayed are all of the mugs, keychains, cedar boxes, t-shirts, and wallclocks a person could possibly want. The other half of the building has food. Giant canisters of canned peaches and similar things of interest to person\'s stocking a bomb shelter or preparing a secured area just in case the government decided to tresspass on their land... Note: the location is an approximation - it\'s somewhere between Columbia MO and St. Louis MO on 70.

properties.name: The Gated Community
properties.description: Posted by Oleander2331 North 58th st philadelphia paThis place is built in such a way that it would make the perfect in-city intentional Community. But, being in Philadelphia it\'s been having a lot of break-ins lately. Reallity aside, it would make a perfect headquarters for great leaders and their families preparing to overthrow the universe!

properties.name: The Square and the Bridge in Prague
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderprague czech republicThere\'s a bridge that I walked along, admiring the bas-relief (sp?) images all along the wall, when I came across children reaching up to touch one of the images. They were so intent on putting their fingers on a specific spot that one child lifted another just enough to reach the image (because neither to get to it on their own). When they scampered off I took a closer look. The spot they touched was worn shiny and smooth from the touch of fingers over the years. I reached up and touched it myself without knowing exactly why it was important but being well aware of the truth about children - if it\'s a lucky charm, they\'ll know where it is.

properties.name: The Tiny Waterfall
properties.description: Posted by OleanderDubuque IowaSomewhere in this region there is a state park with the tiniest waterfal I have ever seen. It flows into a round pool of dark bluegreen water and simply hums with the energy of fairy folk.

properties.name: The abandonded School
properties.description: Posted by Oleander 2331 N 58th street philadelphia paI think this is the place, but I\'m not sure. It\'s a giant school (looks like a high school) with a complete baseball/soccer/etc field. It\'s also got all of the windows boarded up and gates all around. It\'s a perfect place to hide, or conduct secrete business - like breeding and raising dragons made from the genetic matter of humans and baby killer sharks. It\'s a Sci Fi movie just waiting to happen!

properties.name: YANOMAMI, 1934-present
properties.description: Posted by OleanderSurucucus mountain range venezuelaI\'ve searched all over the internet for more details about the Genocide attempts against the Yanomami and have only found bits of information here and there. What it comes down to is land and resources. the Yanomami live on land that the government and minors and developers want. At this point the tribe as been deemed a \'problem\' by the government.
